resource.string: Ba'al Hammon has granted wisdom to us all today. I shall offer sacrifice.
This morning, when I awoke, the cock did not crow. It was, I thought, an ill omen, and I was right…
The hand of Ba'al Hammon is truly upon you if you show such wisdom in acceptance.
Think on this: blood will pay for all that goes amiss from this day forward. That will settle all accounts.
Your wit and wisdom burn brighter than the Sacred Flame!
Very well. Ba'al Hammon has not granted you wisdom in this, but the gods move as they will.
The people of Carthage thank you for your acceptance.
If this is your will, so be it.
You have served your people well, my thanks. And theirs, I imagine.
There is little wisdom in your decision, but so be it.
We have achieved much through our talks this day!
Your wisdom is a credit to your people, it has been an honour!
Very well, our talks are at an end.
We march our armies on other roads from this day on.
We have agreement! Come, share a cup of wine with me!
Carthage has an ageless heart that remembers every slight…
You have shown your worth as rulers. These lands would do well under your control, if you will have them.
My honourable master will leash in his mighty armies.
Excellent! Now, let us eat together as friends!
Someone will make your people bleed for every foolish word you have spoken this day.
Our gods have spoken. These lands are not to be ours, but we wish to give them to friends…
Ah, this is unfortunate, but we will agree. Our armies will no longer enter your domains.
We offer you these lands, for the omens and portents for our mastery have been unfavourable.
We, the people of Carthage, request an attack on these animals.
We humbly request that you teach these fools a hard lesson.
If you were to attack these people you would find Carthage in your debt.
Our agreement will bring much joy to our peoples!
Clearly your gods have not gifted you with wisdom.
Carthaginians achieve the unachievable. But not even we would think this right!
We Carthaginians are a proud people. We do not bend the knee!
I should take your tongue for your impudence!
Away with you and your creatures of darkness! Away, I say!
The people of Carthage want no more of you or yours!
Remove your armies from the lands of Carthage, now!
Such an attack might be prudent, but I do not believe the Senate will make troops available.
Our legions have their orders. Sadly for you their orders do not include acting on your orders.
The Senate sees little need to expend swords and coin from Rome's purse on ill-judged adventures.
The only gold I will give you is the piss from my slaves, and I begrudge you even that!
The feeble and weak-willed may throw you meat, but we do not hold with feeding stray dogs.
You think me a fool then? Or my people? Or our ancestors? One coin, and your begging would never end!
End Non-Aggression Pact||Do you want to end your non-aggression pact with this faction?
Peace Treaty
No more talk. Now is the moment for the swords to have the next words.
The Gods have cast their dice, and war it will be. Mars will be honoured once more!
Very well, Mars will buckle on his armour to defend Roman honour. Look to your funeral arrangements!
You declare war on the Rome? Ha! Make sacrifice to your gods of the dead, for you will soon meet them!
War is the Roman way! The Senators will sacrifice to Mars and Jupiter! Look to your imminent defeat!
War is a well-trodden road for Romans. We will not flinch or turn aside.
Very well! There is nothing closer to the true heart of a good Roman than the prospect of war and the spilling of enemy blood!
So be it! Put your wives and children to the sword, and save them from slavery at Roman hands!
The legions will meet this challenge. The men grow bored when they cannot look forward to a battle!
Your words are olives, picked from a blighted tree. They look well enough, but taste foul.
Such ripe words have their place, but I do not agree to the meat of your proposal.
My people will not agree to such a proposal. It is philosophically offensive to them.
Your rhetoric and logic cannot be faulted but, somehow, your arguments lack a convincing flavour. I do not agree.
Dull words rarely cut through sharp disagreements. We cannot accept your offer.
By the gods! You show a rare wit in your proposals, but we cannot possibly agree to them.
Your words seem fair and just at first hearing, but I cannot agree after thought has done its work.
You are strong and wise, and yet I wonder why you stand aside from this war. I beg you: fight!
Your men will turn the enemies' bowels to water! Come, aid us in this war, I beg!
Join your mighty strength with ours in this struggle. I ask for my people's sake.
Broken treaties with
No. No. Such an arrangement offers comfort only to your people. We would find your words a hard couch indeed!
No. Athena has lent you wits, and Hermes speed in your speech, but Zeus was stingy with the truth…
I humbly ask that you at least consider a formal treaty. Strong defences need good foundations.
Our joint enemies would tremble if we were your allies. Your strength, our wisdom, together, would achieve great things.
You are wise enough not to sit idly upon the bank, but to take the fish as it swims by…
Can you not see? Together, our armies could be nigh-invincible! The world will tremble before our collective might!
Glory, wealth, and a place in the histories. All of these will be ours when we are united as friends!
As all the gods look down on us they, too, must wonder why we are not firmer allies and friends…
Receiving money
Our talk has gone from door to hearth and back again, and without result. It is time to stop.
Your talk has wandered along too many paths. I am lost, and ready to go home! No more talk today!
Stop! Stop! Even the gods grow weary listening to your bleating! Let me have ale now, not shrewish chit-chat!
Come, come! Open your purse and allow the Roman eagle to wet its beak a little!
Some in the Senate have, I am told, lavish tastes. They will fondly remember those who fund such tastes.
Your mind is awash with word-ale! You have said much, and nothing at all. Enough, then…
Even your God of Gossiping Women must have grown weary listening to your endless drone! Stop!
Surely you would wish to be honoured as a friend of Rome by contributing to her coffers?
You are brave indeed, to reject the shelter offered by the hand of Pharaoh, the all-defending.
Before the final journey to the Underworld there are many partings. This is but one more.
Very Friendly
Very well. Words have been wasted. Time will not be wasted in killing you all.
Set aside the friendship of Pharaoh, from whom all blessings flow, and go into the darkness. Such is your path.
A strange choice, to reject the friendly hand of Pharaoh, all-wise-all-knowing, in this fashion…
I trust this courageous decision will not be one that you regret, as the crocodile said to the impetuous swimmer.
Walk your own path into the desert. But do not expect Pharaoh, the all-wise, to give you water…
The mighty Pharaoh, strength be His, has noticed that his treasure house is in some need of replenishment…
In his wisdom and prudence, Pharaoh, numismatist of heaven, desires that his store of coin be increased…
Mighty Pharaoh, the steward of the Earth, desires Egypt's coffers be filled with a reasonable amount of gold…
"Were I to lay awake all night, staring at the Moon, my answer would still be a resounding ""No."""
Unfortunately, your soldiers are largely unwashed and foreign. They would disturb noble Pharaoh's peace.
Respectful visitors who come to gaze slack-jawed upon Egypt's wonders are welcome, but not when they come armed.
The Pharaoh, unto whom all roads lead, cannot agree to let your armies march where they will.
Break Military Access Pact with:
Your people are lower than camel dung, drying in the desert sun, yet you propose a treaty? Bah!
You insolence is well attested and demonstrated. Be careful, or I will demonstrate some inventive cruelty!
You mistake politeness for concern as to your wellbeing. If all your people died, I would merely thank the gods.
Mithra's hairy bulls! Your sickening ideas of what is right and proper are beyond my understanding.
By the flame! I will not cast away all reputation by clambering into bed with a leprous whore!
Our generals would flay my hide and use it for a drumhead if I shackled them to your walking corpses!
Pray to your gods of the dead. Your foolishness has awoken the might and anger of Rome.
An end to talk. The Senate will be pleased to add your lands to Roman domains!
Praise be to Mars! Let us have an end of talk, then, and meet as proper men in open battle!
So be it. You invite a storm and Romans will gladly aid Neptune in bringing one to you!
You have brought this on yourselves. Your people will curse your name when rivers run red with their blood.
All Rome looks forward to seeing your leaders strangled, very, very slowly, during the triumphal celebrations!
How would you like your defeat commemorated? An arch in Rome, or a nice column, or by the wailing of your enslaved people?
You have destroyed yourself today. You have orphaned children and despoiled your women. By Mars, these things will happen!
So you choose the sword. I trust your people will rightly thank you for bringing them a Roman war.
My ba would wander the winds in shame if I agreed to such nonsense.
"My heart would outweigh the Feather of Truth many times over if I said anything other than ""No""."
There is virtue in you, if not in your words. I cannot agree, but do this with regret.
The scorpion's sting is more gentle than a refusal, but a refusal is all I can offer.
O! Pharaoh! Strength and wisdom to you! Grant me the wit to refuse this proposal politely!
I will not trouble Pharaoh's ears, may blessings fall on him, with this proposal. Consider your words rejected!
The Pharaoh, blessings on His seed and numberless children, will undoubtedly wish me to smile slightly as I reject your proposal.
Rome does not offer peace easily but, to such as you, there is no shame is asking whether or not the time of peace is upon us.
Your fine goods would be welcomed in Rome! Trade would see us all prosper, do you not think?
Your warriors do you much credit. Now, can your diplomats and envoys be equally worthy in seeking peace?
There is much to value in the goods of your merchants. Will you not send them into Roman lands?
As enemies you have been without equal in courage and honour. Now, however, the Senate wishes only peace with you.
We Romans admire your merchants and their wares. We would both gain if trade was open between us.
Your people have demonstrated much courage, but is it not time to now put aside the sword?
Rome legions and your armies have long contended in the field but the Senate feels that the time for peace has come.
"Even if Bastet herself offered me the Sun and Moon, I could not say ""Yes"" to this proposal."
Such a proposal would not reflect well on the glory and goodness of Pharaoh, and so must be rejected.
The Senate respectully asks for peace. What good is war?
What makes you think you are worthy as allies of Pharaoh, the Light of His people, when you should crawl in His presence?
On your knees, insolent jackal! Now, beg forgiveness for this presumption, this... this stupidity! This heresy!
Friendly actions towards enemies
Your impudence is most interesting. I wonder if it would seem so appropriate to you in a pit of scorpions?
Bah! Why should Pharaoh, lord of the Two Niles, shackle himself to your corpse in the name of cowardly safety?
Ah! Are Egyptians particularly stupid? Why would we want formal ties to your obviously inferior kind?
Do my ears hear right? You expect Pharaoh, master of an age-old divine land, to have formal ties to upstarts?
Gold is strange stuff. It has the power to harden or soften men's hearts. Perhaps you would like some?
The gods look favourably on those who do good deeds. Therefore, we offer you these payments…
Our treasure houses bulge, and we would share some of that wealth with you, our friends!
Your money may win favour among whores but we will not be used for your filthy pleasure.
Be grateful that you are not eating this mighty treasure, piece by piece, with boiled leeks. You insult honour!
Your gold has a taint about it that cannot be washed off the fingers. We do not want it.
Your wealth will buy you many slaves to sate your lubricious and disgusting tastes. It will not buy us.
Our merchants love gold, our people love gold, my master loves gold. But none of them love your gold!
I am sorry, my friend, but our gods would be much offended by the presence of your soldiers.
Our gates must remain closed and barred, even to your glorious armies.
My lord is brave, warlike and enjoys the manly company of soldiers, but not of your soldiers.
The Senate will turn to Rome's legions and they will set their swords to your people.
That distant noise is the sound of your slumbering foes awaking to a day full of promise. For them.
The Gods of Olympus will look to our safety. Let us hope you are not visited by the gigantes…
Perhaps you will find profit in setting aside our friendship? Although, for the life of me, I wonder where…
We will respect your decision, even though it denies rational thought and good sense.
I fear this ending will tempt beggars, bandits and wolves to come to both our doors…
This is a bold decision and one that I hope you will not regret in days to come.
One sacrifice is needed, on the altar of our goodwill. I speak of gold, of course…
Your words have virtue in your ears, but in mine they are the harshest of desert storms.
Between friends, the gift of gold is often taken to be a sign of deep affection and respect…
We are a mighty people, well versed in the uses of wealth and power. And so we love gold…
Non-aggression Pact
Military access ||By having a military access pact you can trespass upon this faction's territory without diplomatic penalties.
Must we continue this game? Now is the time to accept Carthage as your master!
Men should know when they are conquered.
The people of Carthage are not unreasonable. They simply request that you accept us as your masters.
Merchants do not rule in Rome, and so the Republic does not pay taxes to others.
Sadly, our coffers will remain firmly closed. Roman gold does not travel well.
Empty our coffers? I do not see how this benefits Rome at any time, or in any way.
In his infinite wisdom and divine rationality, Pharaoh is pleased to grant you mastery of these lands…
Pharaoh, all honour be His, in a spirit of friendship, is pleased to give you control of these lands.
The Lord of the Two Egypts, most high Pharaoh, grants you stewardship of these lands, if you wish it.
Our defences are weak, and our old folk know fear. Can you send men to help against the foe?
I have a fine collection of liars' tongues, would you like to see it?
Our foes circle like wolves. My people fear, and I must beg help from you, our sworn friends.
The people of Carthage are fond of gifts. Friends often present them with generous gifts for no apparent reason...
I ask for my people, not myself. What help can you send? Such is our plight that I will… beg... like a woman…
Carthaginians are wise, they understand that a thoughtful gift can carry many meanings….
All men enjoy receiving gifts, Carthaginians are especially fond of them…
We strongly urge you to attack here, and to do this with an almost-Roman efficiency!
This is no time for timidity! In Rome's name, I insist that your armies march against these creatures!
I am sure that you will agree with Roman wisdom, and see the absolute necessity for an attack here.
The wise council of defence must prevail: can you not send aid here?
In his wisdom, and military genius, many Senators feel that your aid in defence would be timely. Will you help?
Rome calls on your armies. There is a threat from these people and we must both guard against it.
Reliability ||The less reliable a faction is, the higher the chance it will turn against its allies if given the opportunity. Be wary of unreliable allies: watch your back!
You are worthy masters but these lands would prosper under our guidance. Your wisdom surely admits this.
I will not beg for these lands, but say that they would be better with us in control. Can you not see this?
This land is surely an unnecessary burden for you. Please, let us lighten your load…
Fine! If we must talk at least be about it quickly!
Do get to the point! Your appearance and odour offends me!
You are a satrapy of this faction.
I find the heat leaves me unable to suffer fools, so speak!
Does this pass for speech where you come from?
You are welcome, but not that welcome… do not sit down.
Break Trade Agreement with...
It would be wise to speak honestly, if you wish to keep your tongue.
I will use small words so that you can understand, my foreign friend: Keep. Your. Troops. Out. They cannot enter.
Speak, scorpion! I would have you from my sight with all possible haste!
Pleasantries be cursed! Speak, you unworthy worm!
Your men are fine fellows from a distance. Close up, on our lands, they resemble brigands, dogs and lepers!
Deliver your message and be gone back to your hovel.
Do not send your hapless armies inside our borders. The stench makes crops rot in the field.
Cancel Alliance
Our gods and my master are restless while your armies move in our lands. Can you remove them?
I would not trouble you with this matter, but our gods are offended. Please remove your warriors from our lands.
I must now speak on a painful and humbling subject: your soldiers have violated our lands. Please remove them immediately.
Your heavy tread has disturbed Roman lands for the last time. Your armies may no longer enter our territory.
Your ridiculous marching about in Roman territory disturbs the people and so must end. Right now.
Our borders are closed to your armies. Senators do not sleep well when foreigners march in Roman lands.
My Lord, the chosen of Ra, commands that your goods and merchants are not welcome in His beloved lands.
Pharaoh, wisest of the wise, believes your merchants work against Egypt's interests. All trade is suspended.
Divine Pharaoh, having considered your wares, does not wish to see His people cheated. Trade is at an end.
A non-aggression pact slightly improves the relations between factions. It is an ideal first step in building good relations.
Why does one so worthy keep a bond to anyone so detestable? Will you not rid yourself of commitment?
My master worries for your souls and your honour, my friend. He cannot sleep while you keep such allies…
Your arrangement with these people does you scant credit. Do your gods not mutter of their displeasure?
Excellent! Now let us drink to ease our throats, and listen to music to ease our ears!
I had hoped that you were a philosopher, and marshalled reason and good argument. I see I was wrong.
Ah! I knew we could agree. Let us go and give thanks to… Dionysus, for there is good wine here!
Logic has been sorely lacking in our disputations. I cannot agree to this, even though the gods will be uneasy.
My thanks for your careful deliberations. I go to offer sacrifice to Athena, who has blessed us all with wisdom.
You have spoken much, but little of it has been rational or clear-headed. I cannot agree.
Your new offer is fair. I swear by Zeus that, for our part, all will be as we have agreed.
These terms are not generous, and our talk is over long. Your wits have obviously been stolen!
You have served your people well today. This acceptance has earned you respect and the blessing of Athena!
After consideration worthy of your counter-offer: no. My respects, but you have proposed too little.
I accept! Let this hard-won accord be a sign from Apollo of more to come.
This is not pleasing. I expected an honourable proposal, yet still wisdom eluded you.
If mighty Carthage wants your gold, we will take it!
How dare you insult the people of Carthage with your unworthy offer?
You do not want to know where I intend to shove your gold!
Payments (Gift)
Speak quickly and well. Speak ill or slowly and I may feed your tongue to the dogs.
Carthage requires a steady stream of revenue, we would be most pleased if you could provide it.
Are you brave or foolish? Or just mad? Well speak, I will listen before I turn you inside out!
A little money entering the coffers of Carthage from time to time would be greatly appreciated.
Gods of the Afterlife… spare my arse! Well, why do you trouble my digestion today?
The upkeep of mighty Carthage is costly, perhaps you could assist us?
I am sure you have many pleasantries for me but, please, don't bother. Talk of meat, not honey.
Come now, see sense. Mars insists that Rome's soldiers be allowed to march where they will in your lands.
I have little to gain in wasting the day on you. What you say had better please my ears!
The Senate suggests that you wisely open your borders to Rome's legions.
My time is better spent feasting and hunting than listening. So be quick with your chattering.
You would be foolish indeed to stand in the path of Senate's legions.
Welcome. Speak. Come on. Do not waste time better spent at hunting.
Come, come, let me hear your talk. I warn you I have no stomach for the meek or nice.
You have the ear of my people. Do not waste words. We are worthy of better.
My most honourable lord and master bids me greet you as befit your station, and to speak in his name.
Listen, for I speak in the name, and with the authority, of my most majestic and warlike lord!
In the name of my most dread lord, greetings. He sends me to speak in his mighty stead.
I have words for the ears of the worthy. For the unworthy, I have only scant regard and less love!
I do not think that the Senate would approve of Roman troops being used like that. They would think it unmanly.
I bring greetings from my most benevolent lord and will speak to you as long as this does him no disservice.
Greetings to you as befits your position. I speak the words of an honest lord. Listen well!
We have no wish to see these lands suffer a conqueror's tread, yet we cannot march to defend them.
I bring mighty words from my master, pregnant with god-granted wisdom. Listen carefully, and well!
Such a plan cannot be countenanced by the Senate at the moment. You must act without Rome.
I speak only to gain your acceptance of my lord's offerings. You would do well to heed my words.
I am not here to debate, dissemble or over-haggle. I come seeking acceptance of proposals made.
We Carthaginians know much of the nature of trade-- enough to know we want none of yours!
The people of Carthage have spoken: your merchants are no longer welcome.
Our tastes have changed. We no longer desire your wares.
On this matter, the gods, the omens and my bowels are as one: get your armies out of our lands!
Your vagabond armies have left their stink in our lands for too long. Remove your slaves!
We will have our shepherds chase your flocking armies, unless they leave of their own accord!
Carrion birds gather. Swords are being sharpened. This is not the time to stand alone. Come, be allies!
I ask a small thing: that you give my people a gift, a token, of friendship.
We, the people of Carthage, come to you in our hour of need.
You enjoy a fine reputation among my people already, but a gift would make your worth clear even to doubters!
We could stand, like brothers, with shields overlapped in the wall, our blades in hand, and defy the world!
Your armies are the envy of the world, perhaps they could come to our aid?
I ask you, doing you proper honour, as befits a warrior folk, to be our allies. Come now, be brave!
You are known as people of wealth and worth. A small gift would make you generous as well!
We would appreciate your assistance with our defences.
We want you as friends of our people. So will you accept the hand of friendship, or turn away?
Will you be counted as friends, or will you walk you’re the crow road into a dark future?
I like friends. I like making friends. We could be friends. Then I wouldn't have to kill you. Just enemies.
Do not attempt to sweeten truth with honey. Speak plainly, and I will deal honestly. Flatter, and you fail…
Military access removes the diplomatic penalty for trespassing on another faction's territory.
I am the trusted voice of my lord and demand the attention of an honest audience.
[Placeholder - Used by code only]
Our treasuries are not full because we are given to charity. Quite the opposite, in fact…
Ah, my friend, I would spare you further embarrassment! We cannot simply give you money.
We do not open our coffers to please the whims of foreigners, even friends.
Is this wit among your people? I should cut out such a witty tongue to show to divine Pharaoh!
You seek to take the lands of Egypt? Rash little fool! Pharaoh's divine anger may yet strike you dead!
Tell me: do you wish to be eaten by crocodiles, or crushed by hippopotami? I only ask because politeness matters…
Us? We should serve you? As your tethered goats? Your dogs? Your slaves? Your head injury goes unhealed, then!
I say my defiance is as sharp as a sword, as true as the arrow, as strong as a stallion!
My people bow to man, least of all the snivelling, shit-biting weaklings that pass as your rulers!
Your wealth is famed throughout the world, as is your generosity! Surely my master can benefit from both?
Much ale will be swilled thanks to your words of agreement. My thanks!
I fear my ancestors and spirits of the land will speak of their displeasure. And when that happens…
We must bow before you in a humble request for gold, for our coffers empty too readily…
Your wealth has been long revered by my master and we ask but a small share…
An attack would be prudent. What say your generals? Are they courageous? Are they eager?
The Senate feels that an attack here would be of great mutual benefit. Could you arrange such an offensive?
Rome has much respect for your might. Will you justify our admiration and act in this instance?
Does your greed know no bounds?!
You are little better than jackals! Away with you!
Mighty Carthage does not share its wealth with brigands and pirates!
Our gods are old, bloody and demanding, but even they think this war is wasteful. Shall we have peace?
We have fine goods and you doubtless have much that we would find desirable. So, are we to have trade?
How much blood must we spill before we find wisdom and end this struggle?
All would surely benefit if we agreed to open trade from this day on. Well?
Do we fight until both of us are on our knees? Our peoples deserve more! They deserve peace!
A river of goods and coin between our lands would surely see all prosper. Will you agree to trade?
I have been to the circle of trees, and listened to the spirits. They speak of nothing but peace…
Strength and bravery have been shown by the living and the dead. Now it is time to set aside war…
Our rivals circle like carrion crows, and we fight on to give them meat. We should have peace.
Break Military Access...
My master will smile, and have us both skinned, if I do not reject this foolish demand!
In your filthy hands these lands would wither like ill-cut vines. Do not take us for fools!
May your soul be as dust! These people deserve better than to be playthings for your wicked perversities.
Your friends shame you. It would be wise to cast them aside.
Free yourselves from these vile creatures.
We would have you break your treaty with these unworthy creatures.
Are you honest warriors, who will come to a brother's aid? Will you send your spears against these enemies?
I call now for you to take to arms against these human wolves. Give your warriors leave to fight!
Can you not attack these folk? Your bravery in this would surely be worthy of a bard's song!
You have offended Pharaoh, the Lord of Two Lands. Remove your army of vagabonds and wastrels immediately!
How dare you pollute the lands of Pharaoh, the divine son of heaven? Remove your filthy troops immediately!
The Pharaoh, His merest whim is a blessing, is rightly angered. His fury is directed at your trepsasses. Remove your men! Now!
Talk can be tasteless, but when we have agreement it makes wine sweeter and gives meat savour!
My words were heard in good faith then. You have proved worthy with this acceptance.
My belly rumbles for food, or the gods prepare a storm! On your head be it!
Excellent! My people will feast me handsomely because of this news!
My people looked for a feast tonight, but your goatish stubbornness has killed all appetite!
The gods bless you with wisdom! And my people will greet your acceptance with arms outstretched!
I spoke with an honest tongue, and trusted you to find the warrior's worth in my words.
Wisdom and strength: together in the service of our people we have agreement.
Gods give me strength! Have we jabbered on for so little result?
You have the iron strength of the sword within your heart to speak such wise words! Excellent!
Your words carry a weight of sadness. I hope your gods gave you wisdom in this choice.
Much talk can be wearisome, unless it brings agreement, as here. So, where's the wine?
The best ale is of little comfort to a dry throat when talking results in nothing.
You speak wisely, like a man of many winters, and I am honoured with this agreement.
This is troubling. You have rejected the word of my people. Unhappiness will flow from this day.
My people value strength and courage, but wisdom too should be admired.
I am loyal to my mighty gods, but I fear their fury at this act of foolish men.
More defenders are needed. I trust that we can rely on your prompt and fulsome support.
The Senate instructs me to ask-- no, demand-- that you aid in the defence against these people!
The Senate feels sure that you will be of one mind with all Rome, and see that defence here is necessary.
(Placeholder) State Gift %d amount for %d turns
Military Access
The harmony of all Carthage is troubled. Ba'al Hammon is uneasy. Please remove your warriors from our land so that all may be well.
Surely your men would be happier in their own homes?
The presence of your armies disrupts our Sacred Flame.
Hail! At the Senate's request I give ear to your just and undoubtedly noble requests!
Come back when you have ordered your thoughts, fool!
I am ready to throw myself into the ocean! A watery grave would be preferable to your prattle!
Your words are not those born of a sane mind! Be gone, before you taint me with your madness!
Remove yourself, my mind runs to dark places when I am sorely vexed!
Surely you can see that it is now time to break all treaties and agreements with these worthless brigands?
I will hear no more! You have already wasted too much of my time!
These people are no better than sand-dwelling thieves and grave-robbers! Surely you will set aside all treaties with them?
I refuse to dignify this nonsense with a response!
Pharaoh, lord of all betwixt dawn and dusk, wonders if you would break your treaties with these mundane folk.
I offer this now, because the gods wish it. I may not make this offer again.
Hermes speed your acceptance, for my people have been most generous in offering even this much!
Give careful thought to this offer. My people expect acceptance and, if Athena helps you, they may have it.
This is what I offer for my people, as blessed by the gods. Think carefully and be prudent.
Athena inspired us in our wisdom. I suggest that you too should listen to her counsel in this matter.
By Zeus, do not take this offer lightly. I make it now in friendship, but that can change…
The words of the Oracle influenced our choice of proposal. Therefore, give your consideration appropriate seriousness.
Accept the terms. Consider the alternatives, and you will see that there is very little sense in anything else.
We are not inclined to bully or overawe, but you should consider your position carefully before you answer.
Non-Aggression Pact
By order of Pharaoh, divine master of Egypt and lesser lands, remove your troops forthwith!
I will hear no argument against Pharaoh, Lord of the Two Houses. Your soldiers will leave His lands!
My master's wishes are quite clear. Dread Pharaoh, in His hands the scourge and the rod, orders your troops to leave! NOW!
In Rome's name, be welcome, and speak in friendship! I will give a receptive ear to your words.

Welcome, and let us be honoured by your attendance and your words.

Divine Pharaoh, brother and beloved of Isis, would have me agree to your proposal, of that I am sure!

Your offer would never be pleasing to Pharaoh, the beloved of Isis, for He is wise beyond your mortal measure.

In the Rome's name, greetings! I come, as an Senatorial servant, to seek answers to questions of mutual interest.
The gods will rejoice at the words we have spoken today. You honour us with these terms.
In the name of the Rome, salutations! Let us speak as friends, and conclude any business in mutual satisfaction.
This agreement is like a feast after an empty belly! You are a truly worthy friend!
Hail! The Senate and People of Rome send greetings and a proposal.
Yes! Your words show wisdom beyond your years. I knew your people to be honourable!
I will take word of our agreement and put it before my people. They will feast in celebration!
From the Senate, greetings and respect. From the People of Rome, honest words.
All praise to the gods! They have led us to wise speech and heart-felt friendship! I agree!
Hail! Rome greets you, and I am sent to speak on her behalf in many matters.
By all the gods, your word-hoard is golden truth! I agree with my heart and tongue to all you say!
Greetings from the Senate and People. I bring words that may bring joy to your ears.

Rome desires me to speak the Senate words to you, that we may come to a satisfactory end.
I come to offer greetings, terms that may prove agreeable, and Rome's honourable pledges if necessary.
I accept. When two ride on the same camel they become better friends! Or, ha! They slit each others' throats!

We can ask no more. Your proposal is wise, honourable and, I hope, pregnant with future profit!

These beasts slumber, but they could wake to hunt us both. Will you strike while they sleep?
Declaring war will end any agreements with this faction. This sometimes comes at the cost of deals with other factions, as they will pick sides.
These human wolves circle close. Our women wail in fear… Will you not send help?
We have sacrificed to Ares, but also beg your mortal aid! We are endangered, and would welcome defenders!
Danger is now pressing. I will cast aside pride and beg for your aid, for I fear for my people…
Remove your good-for-nothing thieves from the lands of Carthage, immediately!
There is nothing you can say! Remove your armies from our land, now!
The Senate has spoken: our lands are closed to you and your kind!
My lord instructs your people to obey his rule from this day on. Dare you defy this edict?
Your choice is clear. You can serve my master, alive and with some honour, or die.
Be sensible. Accept the judgement of the gods. Your days of independence are done. Bow before my master!
Your troops are little better than animals! Cage them or we will call a hunt!
Remove your men from our lands, or suffer the consequences!
You have gone too far! Remove your foul armies from the lands of Carthage!
Pharaoh, the sword of heaven, will never contemplate your unwashed filth marching across his lands!
After such insolence to Pharaoh's majesty, I should take your foul skin for a shield cover! Keep your armies away!
The lands of Pharaoh, Horus reborn, are closed now and in future to your foul, polluting tread!

Ask this faction to become your satrapy. If you are strong enough and they accept your offer, they'll gain your protection but lose most of their diplomatic freedom, effectively becoming your puppets.
By the gods, we have war! Sound the horns! Sharpen the swords! You: pray to your foul gods…
We will go to war then. Prepare your souls. You go to meet your ancestors!
Our young warriors crave the chance to earn their rights as men! Your blood will wash away their youth!
Good! Our warriors grew restless. Cutting your throats will be an end to boredom!
Very well. The word-hoard will be locked away, and swords and shields burnished! We will have glory!
Our warriors will march and our women will prepare the victory feast for their return!
War it shall be! We are honest folk and prefer the sharp sword to the lying tongue!
While your warriors remain on Roman land our Senators are inconvenienced. Remove them and their digestion will surely improve!
While your people and their quaint customs delight many Romans, your armies do not. Please remove them.
War! Ah, a good word. Honest. Our men will take your heads... a pity you are not a handsome people!
Have your women bid farewell to their men, for your heads will decorate our standards!
In the name of the Senate and People of Rome, I respectfully request that you remove your warriors from our lands, now.
The wealth of Carthage is vast, and we are a generous people.
We would offer you regular payment that reflects your worth.
The people of Carthage wish to honour you with gold.
They have ended their military alliance with you
We have talked long to reach agreement. Now we must drown ourselves in ale! Ha!
The gods forbid me to say yes, for we have talked too much and said little.
Excellent! We have agreement. Your mouth talks well. Let us see if your belly can hold ale!
Your speech holds much that is good for your people hidden in many words, but less for mine. I say no.
Our word-trade is now ended, and I will accept your proposal. Come! To the ale!
An end to over-long talk! Your offer is not what I want to hear! My throat yearns for ale, my ears for silence!
You speak well, but can you drink and feast as cleverly to seal our bargain? We shall see!
I find but scant meat stuck to your boney words. We have nothing more to talk about!
The spirits have guided us to common sense and agreement. Now, some ale to guide our wits to sleep!
I looked for agreement worthy of ale and song. And I have been saddened not to find it.
Now, we have talked long, but we have agreement. I am content with the day.
My belly grumbles for swine and ale. We must talk no more. The day is done.
It is time to talk, like men, of many things. We can put aside swords for the time it takes to speak a word or two.
I offer this in the name of our people. Let this be a sign of goodwill to come.
I set aside my sword, to speak to you, warrior to warrior. This is the way of the world, for men.
Consult your ancestors, but you will see the merit in the offer I bring from my people.
Our offer is fair and honourable. By the gods, all will be as we agree here!
I am not here to burden you with demands. My offer is what we consider worthy of your people.
I speak as the sword cuts: directly to the bone of the matter. Listen, and possibly give agreement.
It is the nature of warriors to cut to the heart of anything. Consider this proposal carefully.
"We do not have ""the civilized graces"" but we offer our words honestly, from the heart. "
The Senate wonder why you have a treaty with these creatures? Break it, and be free of obligation!
Rome does not understand why you hold to these people. Free yourselves of pointless obligations!
Why do you burden yourself with such unfortunate friendship? Cast aside these fools, and prosper!
Do you take me for a new Leontiades? I will not believe any of your wonderful assurances!
Open our gates to the armies of the untrustworthy? Do you think me old, feeble of mind, or just mad?
Allow this? I will not risk the honour of our women with your ruffians near at hand!
The storm is coming. Your people will have never seen the like. Run for cover!
Our people go hungry, and you have much. Would it not be the act of a brother to share with another fallen on hard times?
My ancestors were practical men when they lived. For good reasons, then, I ask you for some gold.
I make a simple request, and with respect: can you not spare some gold for my people?
Confident
It is a sad day when friends must part, farewell.
Carthage stood by your side, and will do again, if the gods will it. Until then, we look to our own defences!
Some birds cannot be caged and so fly free, my friend.
Such is the way of the world. Friends part. Lovers part. Only the Ba'al Hammon is constant, eternal and just.
Do you cast all your friends aside so easily?
It is known men are as changeable as the seasons. Only Ba'al Hammon is constant.
I do not hold with overlong talk, preferring the axe's edge as an argument. So listen, and then agree…

This faction is a satrapy of yours ||They can't start a war, have allies of their own, and your enemies are shared. They also send you a sum of money in tribute each turn. Tribute you receive per turn: %n
Consider cancelling a treaty that is not in your best interest. However, there will be a diplomatic relations penalty for doing so. Also, doing so prematurely may be considered treachery.
Gold. Gold. Gold.The people of Carthage require gold.
Why bandy words when gold is involved? You have it, we like it.
The people of Carthage place great value on freely given gifts of gold.
There is much worthiness in making and abiding by treaties, particularly with Pharaoh, the honour of Egypt.
A treaty is a worthy thing. A treaty with Pharaoh, the Lord of the Nile, is worthy twice over.
I offer you honourable treaties and aid against mutual enemies. So speaks my lord Pharaoh, the chief ornament of Egypt.
I would speak of treaties, as between equals. That is the import of my mission for divine Pharaoh.
I do not lightly speak of treaties and permanent agreements. I am the honest servant of divine Pharaoh in this matter.
Military Access
Pharaoh, highest of the high, would have a treaty with you. There, honesty is the best approach in these things!
Divine Pharaoh will be pleased at your acceptance. Any step along the path of wisdom is a good one.
I fear that Sutekh has placed doubt and confusion in your hearts. Pharaoh, from whom mercy flows, will be saddened.
Thoth has guided you from doubt to wise action. He is a kind god, in his way.
Glorious Pharaoh's humble servant does not understand your reluctance, but will carry word of it to Egypt's master.
Thoth, in his wisdom, has come after much talk from us, and aided our deliberations.
Wisdom, then, is fled into the desert like a goat-stealing brigand if this is all we have after so many words.
For your agreement, the thanks of Pharaoh, the heir of Amun-Ra. Let your words weigh true in the balance!
I am saddened that wisdom is unknown among your people. Pharaoh, the guide of souls, will be equally sad.
Unworthy servant to the mighty that I am, I thank you for your acceptance.
The Lord of Two Lands, the Father of Wisdom, will not understand your decision, but it is yours to make.
Your acceptance is a welcome as a cool evening breeze after the desert's heat. My thanks.
I hope you are wise in this decision. Pharaoh, whose might encompasses the earth, will be disappointed.
You are wise beyond your years in this acceptance. Pharaoh, the fountain of beneficence, would have me thank you.
Your decision is, I hope, not as foolish as it first appears. Perhaps Thoth will visit you later…
To hear the words of Pharaoh, the Lord of the Two Niles, is a blessing. To accept them, wise indeed.
You may reject the words of Pharaoh, master of the desert, in the morning, and hear them anew at evening.
Your acceptance is most prudent and becoming to your wisdom. Pharaoh, divine master of Egypt, thanks you.
Be welcome, and may Hermes bless your words with appropriate speed, for I have other business today…
A gift, freely offered, and respectfully accepted, often does much to smooth the rocky road of diplomacy…
My people are eager to express their gratitude for a gift, given by you…
My people do not expect gifts. They like them, really like them, but they do not expect them. At all.
Our ancestors are restless! Please, get your soldiers off our lands or suffer the endless curses of our honoured dead!
You jest, foreigner! We do not laugh, for the royal blood is too pure to bow to your filth!
Mars would turn his back on Rome if I heeded this foolish, weakling's proposal.
Your armies must leave our lands. The stench alone causes sows to miscarry, and all our sheep look nervous!
Speak of this again and I will have you disembowelled and sent back to your people in canopic jars!
Stop Rome’s legions? I fear not. Our men must have their glory and plunder!
Your armies must go. One. Two. Three. Four... Five… Have your warriors left our lands yet? Six… Seven…
Ah! So we are come to this. In Pharaoh's name, strength unto Him, I spit defiance in your insolent face!
Imperial anger is not yet spent. Peace does not interest the First Citizen of Rome or his Senators.
I am not surprised you want peace but, sadly for your people, the Senate has little mercy.
Trade with you? We do not believe in wasting the time of honest Roman merchants.
This humble servant of Pharaoh, the river of joy to His people, dares to suggest an attack on these miscreants…
The Senate will not accept such a thing. Our soldiers hunger for glory and are not done feasting!
I am sure your goods are worthy, but Romans have no taste for them at this time.
Pharaoh, the chief of heaven's strategists, asks that you attack these insolent people. They offend Him.
These people are surely as ripe grain by the river, waiting to be harvested! Can you carry out an attack?
There is a time for talk and for peace. Today is not the day.
Roman good taste does not demand the fripperies and geegaws that you offer in trade.
Make Client State
Your choices have been wise, and reflect well upon your people, even in comparison to Egyptians!
Our talk then has been like blossom on the desert breeze: beautiful, but soon dry and worthless.
You have my attention. Speak and try to do it well, for diplomacy is always boring when done badly!
I will listen. I cannot say for how long, for matters of state, and a splendid bowl of olives, demand attention.
They will receive this payment if the deal gets accepted.
We are not known as patient people. Therefore: welcome! Speak to the point.
Welcome. The day is already old, and there is much to do, so if you have words, speak them.
Greetings, in the name of Hermes. Speak but do not deceive with tricky rhetoric, false logic or cloying pathos!
Greetings. Well, do not stand there, mute as though with the tongue cut from your head! Speak!
I give you greeting, and my attention for the next few minutes. Make your case, but without a lawyer's tedium!
Greetings. Do not waste time on ill-chosen words, although an hour or two bathing would have been useful…
I will listen carefully to your words, and then give judgement. So, greetings, and now: business!
Please accept this gift of land from the people of Carthage.
Your acceptance here will bring much satisfaction to my people. My thanks.
I spoke with honesty and this refusal is my payment. Such is the will of the gods…
We offer you our lands in the spirit of friendship.
So it is done! You have shown great prudence in your choices today.
Your decision does not please us but I hope your gods, at least, look upon it kindly.
Carthage has deemed you worthy to rule these lands.
Excellent news indeed. I shall feast, in modest fashion, on olives and good Greek wine.
This discord is far from pleasing but I will accept your reservations on this matter.
We welcome your acceptance. Your wisdom echoes that of Athena herself!
I struggle to see wisdom in this decision and fear this could lead to misunderstandings and discontent.
You serve the gods and your people well with this agreement. I will make sacrifice in thanks of it.
I am saddened that Athena has not given you wisdom to see the merits of our noble offer.
Apollo smile on you for this acceptance. You are an ornament to your city… land… people.
We trust you have thought long on this; this may eventually invite great sorrow for your people.
By the tetractys! You have a good mind in your skull. Your decision here is most excellent.
I wonder what malevolent spirits were whispering in your ear to make you think this was wisdom…
Your people must think you an Aristotle! Your acceptance is most welcome.
You have spoken with clarity of thought and a rhetorical flourish. You have surely earned the favour of your gods.
Are these words from a sober tongue? If so, then I must accept them even as I despair of them…
Pharaoh, son of the Gods, is mortal enough to enjoy gifts. Freely given gifts, of course…
While Pharaoh, mightiest of monarchs, can rightly claim the entire world as His own, gifts are always appropriate…
Any difficulties with Pharaoh, the great architect of Egypt, could be considerably eased with an appropriate gift…
We would be forever in your debt if you ordered your worthy generals to act against these monsters!
The enemy casts a shadow over us all. Will you send your soldiers, a most brave phalanx, to crush them?
Your generals might be the sons of Ares himself! We ask you today to send them against these wicked people…
We are much alike and so, by the flame, there is much sense to a treaty between us.
There is much merit in a treaty between us. So speak the wise at our temples…
A treaty would be an arrow, shot with deadly intent against our mutual enemies…
I propose a simple treaty, between equals and friends. All can profit by this offer.
My lord and his chamberlains see much advantage in a treaty. What do you say?
A treaty between our peoples would see us all stronger and richer. Is there need of further embellishment?
Among your own folk I am sure such idiocy passes for wit! But you are not among your own folk…
Suggest this again, and you will eat your own manhood. Fried, in fat, from your own ample arse!
This is a fine joke, and I laugh even as I spit my defiance in your face!
Ha! Away with your foolishness, before you feel a golden boot at your arse, emissary or no!
The spirits would not let me rest easily if I gave you money and, in the doing, took honour.
Where have you put your people's pride? Is it eaten by wolves, or pecked away by carrion birds? Gold? No.
Wisdom should always be admired, even in small things. Let us hope today's acceptance is a great thing!
This is not pleasing to gods or men. I had expected more from one considered wise.
What? Should I offer myself to the Theban Sacred Band to be used and cast aside? NO!
It is our destiny to row in the same trireme, for a while at least. Recognise this, and know happiness.
We do not offer our trust easily or readily. Take this offer, and enjoy our favour. Refuse, and arouse suspicion…
Apollo's brazen buttocks! Truly, the gods shat you out! And I do not deal with droppings, even divine droppings!
The omens have been read, and the gods decree an alliance. Do not dare defy the gods!
Zeus give me strength! No! Are you moon-struck, poxed, or suffering from divine disfavour?
The crow does not pluck the eye from a brother crow. So what say you to an alliance?
Come now, agree a treaty and see your enemies quail! Ares favours brave acts, after all!
Our rivals are weak, fractious and foolish. Let us formalise our alliance and put fear into them!
Ask the other faction to become your client state. Client states act as defensive allies, and pay tributes to their overlord each turn.
Create Satrapy
Our gods despair of this bloodshed! We plead for an end to the wars between our peoples.
Only the dark gods celebrate this war and its suffering. I ask you to think of this, and give us peace.
We suffer a tormented marriage but a bond can be found. My people appeal for a settlement that will end the hostility.
Many warriors have gone to the afterlife. Even the bloodiest of gods no longer thirst. It is time for peace.
Words can be all that is between people, but we would like trade as well, if you agree it…
You are a worthy foe indeed, but now the killing must end. Will you not give us peace?
The needs of my people are simple: some of your fine trading goods in exchange for our wares. Well?
Too much that was good and honourable has been lost. I beg now for my people: give me peace.
We do not beg for gold, only ask that we can have trade between us.
They have ended their defensive alliance with you
War! Our gods demand it. Our ancestors love it. You, I expect to see mewling like a woman!
We live for battle, we dream of it, we relish it as others do a fat goose! And you look plump.
Fear is your lot! Now come the ravens, beaks agape for your guts, eager for our sword-work!
War! We will make your homes a wasteland, despoil your women, enslave your children and desecrate your ancestor's graves!
You fear us. It is in your eyes, in your stench. And you are right to fear. War comes.
Enjoy this quiet time. It ends now. The storm is coming, a storm of blood to wash you away!
Ah! War! Good! Sword-bite, shield-crash and your screams on the morning air!
War! A man's calling is war, not weakling's gossip! Give me the clash of swords, not wagging tongues!
We will walk the warriors' road together then. At its end stands your funeral pyre. I will bring the torch!
Declare War||Do you want to declare war on this faction?
I come seeking agreement, one that I hope will benefit both our peoples.
The people of Carthage are true friends and loyal.
Carthage has need of great and powerful friends.
When mortal strength fails it is good to have powerful friends.
Carthage needs your support. What say you?
Even the strongest men need friends from time to time.
The day's greetings to you. Speak, for you have my attention as the ear of the august Senate.
For the Senate's part, be welcome. I listen and speak for them in our dealings today.
Rome is, as always, a welcoming host to you. I await your words with an appetite for truth!
Welcome, worthy guest. I trust you bring words that will enhance the honour of your people in Roman eyes.
My salutations, and the good wishes of the Senate and People, to you and yours! Of what would you speak?
I welcome you on behalf of the Senate, and give ear to your words.
In the name of the Republic, welcome. Speak as a friend of Rome or as an enemy, but do so with honesty.
For the Senate's part, welcome. For my part, welcome also, and give me your wisdom.
Atrocities against friends
Welcome, worthy friend. I trust you bring words that honour both your people and Rome.
No. These terms are unworthy of the servants of Ba'al Hammon.
Carthaginians are not fools, you will find no acceptance here.
Carthage cannot agree to these terms.
I have considered your terms and found them wanting.
Do you think me a fool? No.
There is little worth in these terms.
These terms are not to our liking.
I find the shortest words have the greatest impact: no.
We, the people of Carthage, cannot accept these terms.
Your crude wares no longer suit the refined tastes of our people. Trade between us is done.
The Senate has decreed that your merchants should not be welcomed into Rome's territory.
Rome's appetite for your trinkets has faded, and so trade between us must end.
We will come for you, in the night, and nothing will live. Not one creature. That is our war.
I implore you not to let our peoples be separated. United in greatness, do we not all gain?
Past treaties with
We choose friends with care, and when all sit at the same hearth are we not closer than brothers?
My proud people treasure the blood bond between us. Do you not see this? Will you join us?
Rome offers you honest welcome. Speak, friend of Rome and, hopefully, later we will drink to seal our agreement!
Gifts given to
Consider your terms rejected.
You have my attention. Now, do not try to charm, wheedle or cajole. For those, pain is the reward.
Do not expect fine words for, while we have agreement here, there is no respect between us.
I am, in truth, uneasy, but the good of my people requires me to put aside such feelings.
There is little profit in this for my people but I will stop haggling.
My lord will not rest easy but I will accept. Perhaps there will be some profit in the day…
By the flame, you offer little, but today I am in a giving mood. We agree.
My appetite for feasting is entirely fled. The taste of acceptance is sour in my mouth.
I dare not ask much for my people, only a single payment to replenish our sadly diminished coffers…
My people do not like luxury, but money is needed. I ask, humbly, that you give us some small amount.
Perhaps, and I ask with all due respect for your august self, you could let us have some money?
Do not speak of this again, unless you wish to become as Osiris: beloved by his wife, but bereft of manhood.

Your reliability rating ||Acts of treachery, such as attacking your allies, decreases your reliability rating. The less reliable you are, the smaller the likelihood of successful diplomacy. However, betrayals are forgotten over time, allowing you to restore your rating.
The divine Pharaoh, being not blessed by a lack of wit, is not minded to hand over his subjects to your tender mercies.
The Pharaoh, long life to Him, does not treat with slavers and craven merchants such as you.
Be welcome, I suppose. Now, speak as you will, and try to be interesting…
I am here, then. Speak your words, and be sure that I find profit in them!
In time, two things always smell: fish and uninvited guests. Speak quickly, then, before I lose interest, and my breakfast!
Am I always to be disturbed by foreigners? If it is alms you want, talk to my major-domo!
Be welcome, emissary, if you come in peace. Be fearful if you come with false words, dripping with honeyed lies.
Our patience with your errant warriors is done. They are no longer welcome in our lands.
Do not try my patience with a dull tongue. My torturer has a collection of dullard's parts…
We grow tired of the cursing your armies in our lands. We want rid of these thieves!
The door is open to you, but if you wish to go beyond the courtyard within, speak!
Before you say anything, know that I have an amulet against the evil eye. Dark sorcery will gain you naught!
Our lands are closed to you. Your warriors must go. So speak the spirits and our ancestors.
Do not wander in like a desert beggar. If you have something to say, say it like a civilized man!
Declaring war while having treaties or shortly after breaking them is considered an act of treachery and is condemned by all factions!
Your armies don't belong here, remove them.
The senators of Carthage have spoken: you are no longer welcome in our lands.
The borders of mighty Carthage are closed to you.

Ask the other faction to join your confederation. If you are strong enough and they accept your offer, their faction will be assimilated by your own. Their settlements will become yours as may some of their armies or fleets.
Hermes aid my offer of peace, that it may fly from my mouth to your ears with proper haste!
Only carrion birds love war above all things. Men have wisdom to love peace as well. Shall we have peace?
The sword becomes blunted from constant use, the shield broken. Now is the time to consider peace.
We have been honourable foes, but now, together, we must forge an honourable peace. What say you?
Our merchants seek prosperity in your lands. Yours could do the same in ours. Will you agree to this?
Even the rage of Ares passes, and he looks to rest. Surely we can do the same and have peace?
There is good in trade. To walk through a market is to understand a people, and learn to respect them.
Glory, pursued beyond all reason, is no longer glory. It is madness. Shall we have the sanity of peace?
Will you agree to trade? We have much your people might enjoy, and your goods would enrich our markets.
Carthage is not some dirt track for you to march along whenever you deem necessary!
The people of Carthage cannot allow your troops to sully their land.
The eagle does not invite the scorpion into his nest.
Come, sit by me, and we shall share words and wine!
I request, in the name of Rome and her People, that you send aid immediately to defend against these inhuman beasts!
Rome has long admired your magnificent armies. Can you not send a few to defend against these people?
The Senators will never forget a favour, freely and generously given, such as military aid against these people.
Pharaoh, the master of many hearts, has looked into your souls and seen that you are worthy of peace.
Divine Pharaoh would smile upon trade between our peoples. Wealth is always welcome.
Swords have been washed in blood for long enough. What say you to peace with the people of Egypt?
Although gold is beneath the notice of Pharaoh, divine master of Egypt, His servants have mortal, prosaic concerns…
Pharaoh, the just and merciful, is not a bloodthirsty tyrant, and offers peace. Will you not consider this?
My lord Pharaoh, ever mindful of his servants' well being, considers that trade with your people would be wise.
I am ordered by Pharaoh, whose breath perfumes the world, to offer you a just and honourable peace.
The Pharaoh, health and long life to Him, speaks through me, and says but one word: peace.
Will you not have peace? Pharaoh, whose heart knows only love, would give you peace, if you will take it.
See reason, my friend, and follow a profitable course. My lord is a noble master, and rewards loyalty.
My worthy master will be a father to your people, rewarding and chastising as a father.
By sword and flame, bow before my master. Start in humility, and all will be well!

Your reputation precedes you! How can Carthage be of assistance?
Ba'al Hammon bless you my friend, you are most welcome!
It is an honour to hear your words! What do you wish to discuss?
Greetings! I long to hear the wisdom of your words.
In the name of the people of Carthage, you are welcome!
Come, your words will be received with the rapt attention they deserve!
Welcome honoured guest! How may we help you?
Dogs circle us and bare their teeth. We need a friend or two to watch our backs…
The Senate requests that you allow the armies of Carthage to march through your lands. It is just a courtesy.
Will you send aid? A wise man looks to his brother to bring a bucket when the floods come!
We Carthaginians either find a way, or make one. What say you?
The armies of Carthage are akin to fine horses; they need exercising. Your lands are ideal for this!
I speak now of our need for more warriors, to defend against these people. What aid can you send?

My ears are all yours! Fill them with your wise words!
Speak, honoured friend of Carthage, and be blessed by Tanit!
Military actions against
Come now, see reason! Accept my master, the divine Pharaoh, as your merciful lord and protector.
Defiance has gained you little. Accept the lordship of Pharaoh, the sword of the Gods, and your new master!
On my master's behalf, I urge you to see sense! Accept the mighty Pharaoh, the son of Osiris, as your rightful lord!
The pleasures of my household are yours to enjoy. First, though, the necessary burdens of diplomacy…
Rome rightly holds you in respect, for your words and deeds are honest and honourable. However, we cannot agree to your proposal.
Your advocacy was most skilled. For Rome's part, I give voice to an honest and respectful refusal of your offer.
You are plainly a man of honour and no little wisdom, but your terms are unacceptable.
Granted, you have spoken well and set out honest terms but they are not terms we can accept.
I could not, in honour, return to the Senate having accepted such an offer. Therefore, for Rome's part, I reject it.
This offer is made in good faith and, in a spirit of honesty, I must reject it on Rome's behalf.
Your proposals have some merit, but I cannot accept on Rome's behalf.
I am sure you speak with an honest tongue but, for Rome, I cannot greet your words with approval.
You speak well in your cause, but I am not entirely persuaded. I regretfully, and respectfully say no.
The gods gave us those lands. Surely you would not stand in the way of divine generosity?
These lands would benefit from the rule of a philosophical people, a logical people, a mathematical people... Well, us, really…
Surely, you do not need these lands? Surely you can see the bright logic of giving them to us? No?
I never thought your kind capable of atrocities but here we are.
The people of Carthage will curse my name when they hear of this, but it must be done.
We accept, but mark my words, this madness will not end well!
Your kind was spawned in darkness, but with Ba'al Hammon's protection to guard us, we agree.
I will have to sacrifice much to remove the taint of this agreement.
Moloch take thee, and curse thee, but we must, we will, have this agreement.
Mighty Carthage does not bed down with inferior men like a Roman trollop!
What could you possibly have to offer us?!
You presume too much!
Get out of my sight! I should open your throat for your insolence!
The flame and the wood can never be friends; the flame consumes all in its path!
The fact that you dare to ask this worries us. Clearly, we have been too kind.
Rome's purse is not to be plundered to satisfy the over-confident greed of brigands and vagabonds!
You are most insolent, and insolence in Rome is usually repaid with the whip!
You expect golden trinkets to adorn your wives! Those barbarous creatures, fleas, normally settle for a little blood!

My friend, you honour this place with your arrival! I, your humble servant in matters of diplomacy, await your words…
